Title: $f$ is discontinuous $\iff$ kernel($f$) is dense in X
Content:
Problem: Let $X$ be a normed space and $f$ be a non-zero linear functional on $X$. Then prove that $f$ is discontinuous $\iff$
  kernel($f$) is dense in $X$. I have proved that if $f$ is discontinuous, then kernel($f$) is dense in $X$. How to prove the other way?
AcceptedAnswer: Suppose that $\mbox{kernel}(f)$ is dense in $X$. Since $f$ is non-zero, there exists $x\in X$ such that $f(x)=1$. Since $\overline{\mbox{kernel}(f)}=X$, there exists a sequence $(x_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ in $\mbox{kernel}(f)$ such that $\displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty} x_n= x$. It follows that, if $f$ were continuous, we would have $\displaystyle 1=f(x)=\lim_{n\to\infty} f(x_n)=\lim_{n\to\infty}0=0$. So, $f$ is not continuous.
